comments.commentBody: A tour of the fortress is a fascinating experience. The telling of the legend (or history?) of why the citizens of Salzburg are called "Bull-washers"--this helped people in the fortress survive a long siege. Besides, the view down into the medieval city--Mozart's hometown, view of the river Salzach and bridges is breathtaking. And the Alps seem close enough to touch. Make sure you walk through the beautiful cemetery when you come back down with the funicular. History you can hear, see, and feel!
one said cromulent?  That's unpossible!

To Poster 172 (msg in Florida):

Let's hear, say, a jillion - (jillion - 1) = 1 good reason.

[BTW, are you an erstwhile NYer who misses MSG in Manhattan?]
My Irish mom's word for a dread disease:  lollimadiddy of the goo-goo.
My least favorite made up word is "Febyouary", however; I do like frigilator (refrigerator) and freezilator (freezer).

After reading all this, I was reminded that my auto mechanic father-in-law ( RIP), used to tell customers he was changing the "Finnegan Pin" or adjusting the "Murphy Rod". Not nonsensical words, but certainly nonsensical auto parts. The interpretation was supposed to be he hadn't gotten around to fixing that particular vehicle yet.

Dave S. , have you found your "hoo-jee" yet? ( same as doohickey, thingamajig)
Crabalocker. Taradiddle. Ishkabibble.

Snarkled. As in a face bath from our happy puppy's tongue.

Parttimer's and Sometimer's - pre Alzheimer's.
One thing to remember is that Phuket is a large island and it is neither cheap nor easy to get from one place to another.  To get from one beach to another can take well over 45 minutes.

Actually the 2006 UCL final against Barça was not Henry's final game for Arsenal, he stayed in London for another season leaving in the summer of 2007.
About the quarter-final fixtures I'm pleased about the possibility of a French team in the semi-final, hope FCGB make it but O. Lyon seem like the favorites to me based on their European pedigree.
Arsenal v Barça should be a football spectacle, a purist's dream. Two of Europe's best attacking and passing sides facing off don't expect cleansheets!

I did not take his statement about what NOT to do as an insult to MLS; and I don't think he intended it as such.

I like the NZ team and thought their Confederations Cup performance was unfortunate. I hope they do well in the World Cup.

DC United drafted Nelsen out of college, and Nelsen spent his formative first four years as a professional with the team in MLS. In his fourth year, he captained the team to an MLS championship. It was immediately on the heels of this success in MLS that he was able to move to England.

Instead of saying anything at all positive about DC United and MLS regarding Nelsen's professional development, Hall instead takes the snarky route of choosing a single out-of-context quote that implies that Nelsen sees his experience in MLS as doing nothing more than making him "a better player by accident." I am certain that this is not the most important thing Nelsen would have to say about DC United or MLS. Either Nelsen said more and Hall left it out or Hall didn't bother to ask the quality of questions you would expect of someone working for the New York Times.

Nelsen is a good player and class act who DC United fans miss and wish well.
finally

Yeah!!! This is such great news.

And I am curious to see what they worked out.
Interesting fact : there are French players in the first lineup 6 of the 8 qualified teams (for Barcelona, I'm thinking of Abidal, not Henry).

Despite not being able to play, I feel Beckham could still be helpful for Capello and England. Read so on my blog

Why couldn't the league just say, "player salary & benefits will be a certain percentage of league revenue, no higher, & you can have free agency within the league"?
Hallelujah! (...if it's true.)

Jack-

Why no post on Barca's win over Stuttgart on wednesday?
Oh well, there go Everton's hopes of keeping Landon Donovan around a while longer!
Good

compromise was the order of the day.  players traded more guaranteed compensation and an ability for someone else in the league to sign them over full free agency [dont see those words so it hasn't happened].  but the league begins on time, a must for this year....red bull stadium looks great on tv and with union starting up and world cup interruption it is critical to begin on time.

On the face of it, it seems like a win-win situation. MLS is still a long way from being a truly major league and cannot afford the expense of free agency but players do have a little more freedom of movement and, with guaranteed salaries, can feel a little more secure financially. It was good to see urgency and pragmatism from both sides. The imposition of a strike deadline by the players was, happily, not a sign of intransigence. It created the pressure needed to get both sides engaged in a serious give and take.

One would hope that certain other leagues approaching CBA deadlines might take a cue from their younger cousins and put aside posturing in favor of serious,constructive talks.

We went here after reading both the NY Times and the SF Chronicle reviews and were very disappointed. We ordered the roasted asparagus after the waitress recommended it. We were debating between it and the crab bisque - the waitress said the asparagus was "amazing", so we went with that. I had my doubts about $10 roast asparagus, but after the waitress's strong recommendation, I was hopeful. It came and was nicely seasoned, but was mushy, yet stringy at the same time. I had to saw through it to cut off a piece and it scratched my throat going down. We also ordered the oyster pizza, which had nice flavor, but the crust was so soggy and thin, it pretty much fell apart. Our last course was the whole roasted sea perch. It was definitely not properly prepared. It still had scales on it and the flesh had a strange bitter flavor. When we deboned the fish, I discovered some innards or something still inside. After the fish, we decided against dessert and coffee, in spite of the rave reviews for the ice cream sandwich. Overall it was a very disappointing, over-priced meal.

-jlew

I am living, breathing and eating this Iraq War, every day. I am the wife of an Infantry First Sergeant, who the Army sent to prison for "Life in prison", after he led his company in one of the most violent times in the Iraq War, OIF 06-08 which was pre-surge. JOHN E. HATLEY served for 20 years and just turned 41 and due to a convening authority who only reduced his sentence through clemency to 40 years, this is still a life sentence. My husband, John E Hatley and 2 other soldiers were imprisoned for saving American lives. CNN covered our story back in Nov 2009. A retired LTC just yesterday, provided information (research) that the US Army did NOT and does not, have any apparatus that protects our own, in Iraq.

General McChrystal: The "never had a effective detainee policy" statement is derived from a lot of sources. No one, at least in the military, wants or will come out and say they have a bad detainee policy. The primary source is the General McChrystal assessment he sent to the Pres a few months ago. In the assessment he calls for an effective detainee policy...meaning he does not have one now.

The term "detainee catch & release" is not a policy. It is what has been broadcast as such, but ground troops are the ones who coined this term. Our troops have to fight the same enemy combatants over & over again. Please search for my husband's name on the web to find out more. CNN uncovered that in the Iraq War, 87,000 were detained, but 77,000 were released.

I have heard of this movie and would like to see it, but my time is consumed with campaigning for support....for the release of 3 American Soldiers now imprisoned at Fort Leavenworth, Kansas. Perhaps this movie does not represent everything Iraq Veterans think it should, but I certainly hope someone will represent the FLAWS of this war at some point. Now that, is certainly worthy of the making of a movie. Please Americans, don't forget that March 16th was the anniversary of the Iraq war. It's not a monumental day for me, since I live, breath and eat this war, every day since April 17, 2009. Defend our soldiers.

How many of the fallen soldiers in the Iraq War, were taken by "second chancers"? Just how many IED's or VBIED's can be planted and detonated by just one.............just one, second chancer? Think about this. Think about the number of fallen soldiers. Also, think about the ones in Afghanistan, where over 75% of deaths are caused by IED's. See the "96th Hour Rule" covered by CNN and the fact that General Petraeus just the other day, admitted to the Senate Arms Committee that "it is yet another flawed policy and simply does not work". General Petraues a day later, mentions again that another policy is flawed and does not work and is being overhauled in Afghanistan, regarding the training and utilization of Iraqi' police. When I am able to gain the release of all 3 of our soldiers, which one is my husband "John Hatley", then I'll sit down to watch this movie.

KimHatley (3/20/2010)
